results.title: An Experiment in towns
results.creator_credit: John Reeve, Anthony Gilkison and Rayant Pictures
results.brief_description: Shows the reasons why Britain has recently built fifteen towns - to give healthier working conditions, closer proximity to work, and enable “men to lunch in their own homes”. Explains how the planned towns are designed to allow safe play for children and creative leisure for adults. Shows the good design of individual homes.

results.title: Exeter
results.creator_credit: Gerald Budner, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Exeter Cathedral in Devonshire, England, is considered to be the finest example of architecture of the Decorated period, 1250-1350. This film rolls back the centuries, unfolding the cathedral’s history, showing the refinement of the sculpture that went into its building, from the airy vista of the nave (longest unbroken stretch of Gothic vaulting in the world), to the vibrant colors of its windows. But more than architecture survives, Exeter is still a living church for the people of today. Credits include: photography by Pierre Letarte, Reginald Morris, Richard Todd, Gilles Gascon; editing by Margaret Wescott; music by The Dunstable Consort; sound by Ted Haley, Jean-Guy Normandin and Peter Hearn.

results.title: Every five minutes
results.creator_credit: Max Anderson, John Taylor and Basic Films
results.brief_description: Illustrates causes of domestic outbreaks of fire and the precautions to be taken with them. Nearly all fires are caused by carelessness - leaving on electric appliances, using the wrong kind of fusewire, patching up electrical leads, leaving open fires unattended, and also leaving matches within reach of children. Emphasises that while fire brigades are highly trained, well equipped and within easy reach, the best cure for fire is prevention.

results.title: Ever since Giza
results.creator_credit: Ted Davis and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This film tells of the history of barley. A grain of antiquity - seeds were placed in the ancient pyramids of Giza. The experimental work done by Victorian and South Australian agencies to improve the barley crop through the development of more suitable varieties for areas of different climate, standard-isation of seed and better farming techniques is shown. This film was included in the San Francisco Film Festival 1964.

results.title: Essence of life
results.brief_description: Explains and illustrates the main characteristics of a living organism - the ability to reproduce its own species, response to stimuli, movement and metabolism. Studies different forms of life developed on earth as conditions altered, from fresh water to dry land - fish, amphibia, birds, insects, animals and plants.

results.title: ERA : the Educational Reform Association School (TEFC)
results.brief_description: This film gives an impression of the philosophies, day-to-day experiences and development of pupils at the Education Reform Association School at Donvale, Victoria. Students and staff together discuss the aims of the school programme, hopefully providing evidence for greater freedom in all our educational institutions

results.title: The Enduring wilderness
results.creator_credit: Ernest Reid and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A scenic tour of Canada’s national parks, from the mountains of British Columbia to the seaswept shores of Newfoundland. Besides the beauty of the unspoiled wilderness (and there is much of that), you see also the farsightedness of those who in the past century, set aside these territories for the enjoyment of future generations.

results.title: Endurance
results.brief_description: Originally photographed at the time of Shackleton’s attempt to cross Antarctica from the Weddell Sea to the Ross Sea, 1914-16. Travelling from Buenos Aires through 2,000 miles of pack ice, the ship ‘Endurance’ was frozen in and smashed by pressure. Retrieving supplies and three boats the party camped at Elephant Island, while Shackleton and five others set out in terrible cold for sixteen days journey to South Georgia whaling station. Forced to land on the wrong side of the island, they walked 36 hours over a 9,000 foot unexplored ridge to the whaling station. Four expeditions were organised before the main party was rescued without loss. Shows Shackleton’s later expedition in the ‘Quest’ ending with his death in 1922. Photography by Frank Hurley.

results.title: Empire Games, 1962
results.brief_description: The official film of the 7th Empire Games held at Perth, Western Australia. H.R.H. Prince Philip attended the Games. This is a colorful and fascinating piece of Australian history featuring a very young Dawn Fraser in action.
